utterances: Despite all the recent focus on the economy, McCain has tried to change the subject.
He hosted a roundtable discussion in Tampa on national security, an issue where he feels he has the edge.
I know that we are facing difficult economic times.
And I still believe the transcendent challenge of the 21st century is that of radical Islamic extremism.
McCain talked, as he often does, about the many active-duty military and veterans in Florida.
His experience is reassuring to Terry Varvle(ph), who wore a Vietnam veterans pin on his lapel.
I feel safe with someone that knows the world theater, and not the one where they say on-the-job trained.
And that's what I feel like with the other candidates.
Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani offered his own capsule summary of the race in a speech to Sarasota Republicans.
He says Romney is attacking McCain for a shortage of economic know-how, while McCain is attacking Romney for a lack of national security experience.
The choice is clear.
Floridians deserve someone who's been tested and proven in both areas - and that's me.
(SOUNDBITE OF APPLAUSE)

Political analyst Susan MacManus of the University of South Florida says much of their focus will be along Interstate 4, between Tampa and Orlando, an area that often tips the balance between the social conservatives of Florida's northern panhandle and more moderate voters.
Look at all these candidates and where they are in Florida today, and they're clumped right here in that I-4 corridor that we lovingly say in our state is the highway to heaven for politicians.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, Tampa.
Public outrage over bonuses paid to executives of AIG is even pulling disgraced politicians out of hiding.
Eliot Spitzer, former governor of New York, emerged from the media wilderness this week to say I told you so.
His first TV interview since his prostitution scandal aired today on CNN.
NPR's Robert Smith has more.
Watching the interview, it sometimes seemed as if Client Number 9 never went into that hooker's hotel room.
The old Eliot Spitzer was back in his dark suit, red power tie, jutting out that massive chin, but the new Eliot Spitzer wasn't looking to string up the executives of AIG.
(Soundbite of television program)
The search for villains is emotionally satisfying, not terribly useful.
The better effort is okay, what do we learn?
Of course, the same question could be asked of Spitzer.

It was impossible to watch his interview with CNN's Fareed Zakaria without thinking about the last time we saw Spitzer on TV, standing next to his wife, apologizing for his sexual hijinks and resigning as New York governor.
Today, Spitzer seems just as smart, just as judgmental as ever, but it takes the sting out of his indictment of Wall Street when you know he's guilty of some of the same sins.
